Change of Coordinates and Applications to View Matrices

This article introduces the mathematical derivation of the lookAt view matrix commonly used in computer graphics APIs like OpenGL.

As part of the graphics pipeline, the purpose of this matrix is to perform the view transformation, converting global world coordinates into a coordinate system defined by position and direction of an observer.

The derivation is built from from fundamental linear algebra principles, beginning with the interpretation of the matrix-vector product as projections onto an orthonormal basis. This leads to formal treatment of coordinate system changes using change-of-coordinates matrices. By applying these concepts, we construct a final 4×44 \times 44×4 matrix, revealing the precise geometric meaning of both its rotational as well as translational components.

Introduction​

This article introduces the derivation of the lookAt matrix in OpenGL, which is a 4×44 \times 44×4-transformation matrix of the form

MlookAt=(Pcam←worldT⃗3×101)\boldsymbol{M}_{\text{lookAt}} = \begin{pmatrix} \underset{\text{cam} \leftarrow \text{world}}{\boldsymbol{P}} & \vec{T}_{3 \times 1} \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}MlookAt​=(cam←worldP​0​T3×1​1​)

Here, Pcam←world\underset{\text{cam} \leftarrow \text{world}}{\boldsymbol{P}}cam←worldP​ denotes a change-of-coordinates matrix. While T⃗3×1\vec{T}_{3 \times 1}T3×1​ is often referred to as a translation vector - that is, a displacement vector - we will later see in the view matrix that this displacement also involves rotation.

The purpose of the lookAt-matrix is to transform coordinates from world space to camera space, effectively re-expressing world coordinates relative to the camera's point of view:

v⃗cam=MlookAt v⃗world\vec{v}_\text{cam} = \boldsymbol{M}_{\text{lookAt}}\ \vec{v}_\text{world}vcam​=MlookAt​ vworld​

We begin by examining the structure of matrix-vector products, where the matrix rows are interpreted as the vectors of an orthonormal basis1 in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3.
Next, we introduce the concept of coordinate vectors and explain how change-of-coordinates matrices are used to map vectors from one coordinate system BBB into another coordinate system CCC.

Building on these concepts, we conclude by deriving the explicit form of the lookAt matrix to map coordinates between VworldV_\text{world}Vworld​ and VcamV_\text{cam}Vcam​.

To complement the theoretical derivation, we provide an interactive application as a hands-on experience, enabling readers to visualize the effects of these transformations in real-time.

Projections and Matrix-Vector Products​

Let u⃗,v⃗,w⃗\vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w}u,v,w be the orthonormal vectors of the standard basis ε\varepsilonε in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3

u⃗=(100), v⃗=(010) w⃗=(001)\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{u} &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},\ \vec{v} &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\ \vec{w} &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \end{alignat*}u​=​100​​, v​=​010​​ w​=​001​​​

Let p⃗=(pxpypz)\vec{p} = \begin{pmatrix} p_x \\ p_y \\ p_z \end{pmatrix}p​=​px​py​pz​​​ be an arbitrary vector in R3\mathbb{R}^3R3.

We can write p⃗\vec{p}p​ as the matrix-vector product Ax⃗=p⃗\boldsymbol{A} \vec{x} = \vec{p}Ax=p​, where A\boldsymbol{A}A is a 3×33 \times 33×3 matrix whose rows represent the vectors u⃗,v⃗,w⃗\vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w}u,v,w. Since A=AT=I3A = A^T = I_3A=AT=I3​, it immediately follows that x⃗=p⃗\vec{x} = \vec{p}x=p​.

(uxuyuzvxvyvzwxwywz)(pxpypz)=(100010001)(pxpypz)=(u⃗⋅p⃗v⃗⋅p⃗w⃗⋅p⃗)=(pxpypz)\begin{alignat*}{3} \begin{pmatrix} u_x & u_y & u_z \\ v_x & v_y & v_z \\ w_x & w_y & w_z \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} p_x \\ p_y \\ p_z\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} p_x \\ p_y \\ p_z\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \vec{u} \cdot \vec{p} \\ \vec{v} \cdot \vec{p} \\ \vec{w} \cdot \vec{p} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} p_x \\ p_y \\ p_z\end{pmatrix} \end{alignat*}​ux​vx​wx​​uy​vy​wy​​uz​vz​wz​​​​px​py​pz​​​=​100​010​001​​​px​py​pz​​​=​u⋅p​v⋅p​w⋅p​​​=​px​py​pz​​​​

The resulting components px,py,pzp_x, p_y, p_zpx​,py​,pz​ represent the scalar projections of p⃗\vec{p}p​ onto the axes of the standard basis.

Since u⃗\vec{u}u is a normalized vector, multiplying pxp_xpx​ with u⃗\vec{u}u yields the parallel component of the orthogonal projection of p⃗\vec{p}p​ onto u⃗\vec{u}u.
These projections can then be used to reconstruct p⃗\vec{p}p​ as a linear combination of the basis vectors u⃗,v⃗,w⃗\vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w}u,v,w, e.g. for u⃗\vec{u}u:

(u⃗⋅p⃗)u⃗=(u⃗⋅p⃗∣u⃗∣2)u⃗=(u⃗⋅p⃗1)u⃗=(px)u⃗=(px,0,0)T(\vec{u} \cdot \vec{p}) \vec{u} = (\frac{\vec{u} \cdot \vec{p}}{|\vec{u}|^2}) \vec{u} = (\frac{\vec{u} \cdot \vec{p}}{1}) \vec{u} = (p_x) \vec{u} = (p_x, 0, 0)^T(u⋅p​)u=(∣u∣2u⋅p​​)u=(1u⋅p​​)u=(px​)u=(px​,0,0)T

and analogously for v⃗,w⃗\vec{v}, \vec{w}v,w.

Hence, p⃗\vec{p}p​ can be expressed as

(u⃗⋅p⃗)u⃗+(v⃗⋅p⃗)v⃗+(w⃗⋅p⃗)w⃗=(px00)+(0py0)+(00pz)=(pxpypz)=p⃗(\vec{u} \cdot \vec{p}) \vec{u} + (\vec{v} \cdot \vec{p}) \vec{v} + (\vec{w} \cdot \vec{p}) \vec{w} = \begin{pmatrix}p_x \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix}0 \\ p_y \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} +\begin{pmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ p_z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}p_x \\ p_y\\ p_z \end{pmatrix} = \vec{p}(u␀⋅p​)u+(v⋅p​)v+(w⋅p​)w=​px​00​​+​0py​0​​+​00pz​​​=​px​py​pz​​​=p​

Before we generalize this construction to an arbitrary orthonormal basis, it is worth noting that the scalar projections - that is, the weights in the above linear combination - are commonly referred to as the components of the corresponding coordinate vector. For example, the coordinate vector of p⃗\vec{p}p​ relative to the standard basis ε\varepsilonε is denoted by2

[p⃗]ε=px(100)+py(010)+pz(001)=(pxpypz)[\vec{p}]_\varepsilon = p_x\begin{pmatrix}1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{pmatrix} + p_y\begin{pmatrix}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{pmatrix} + p_z\begin{pmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}p_x \\ p_y \\ p_z\end{pmatrix}[p​]ε​=px​​100​​+py​​010​​+pz​​001​​=​px​py​pz​​​
Coordinate-Vector Definition

Let B={b1⃗,b2⃗,…,bn⃗}B = \{\vec{b_1}, \vec{b_2}, \ldots, \vec{b_n}\}B={b1​​,b2​​,…,bn​​} be a basis for the vector space V=RnV = \mathbb{R}^nV=Rn.

Then, every vector x⃗∈V\vec{x} \in Vx∈V can be written uniquely as a linear combination:

x=c1b1⃗+c2b2⃗+…+cnbn⃗x = c_1 \vec{b_1} + c_2 \vec{b_2} + \ldots + c_n \vec{b_n}x=c1​b1​​+c2​b2​​+…+cn​bn​​

The vector

[x⃗]B=(c1c2⋮cn) [\vec{x}]_B = \begin{pmatrix}c_1 \\ c_2 \\ \vdots \\ c_n \end{pmatrix}[x]B​=​c1​c2​⋮cn​​​

is then called the coordinate vector [📖LLM21, p. 256] of x⃗\vec{x}x relative to B.

Change of Basis in Three Dimensions​

Claim: Let A∈R3×3\boldsymbol{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{3 \times 3}A∈R3×3 be a matrix whose rows are orthonormal basis vectors u⃗,v⃗,w⃗\vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w}u,v,w of C⊆R3C \subseteq \mathbb{R}^3C⊆R3.

Then, for any vector p⃗∈R3\vec{p} \in \mathbb{R}^3 p​∈R3, the matrix-vector product

Ap⃗=p⃗′\boldsymbol{A}\vec{p} = \vec{p}'Ap​=p​′

yields the scalar projections of p⃗\vec{p}p​ onto the basis vectors - that is, the coordinates of p⃗\vec{p}p​ relative to the orthonormal basis of CCC.

Proof by Scalar Products​

Computing the Matrix-Vector product

(uxuyuzvxvyvzwxwywz)(pxpypz)\begin{alignat*}{3} \begin{pmatrix} u_x & u_y & u_z \\ v_x & v_y & v_z \\ w_x & w_y & w_z \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} p_x \\ p_y \\ p_z\end{pmatrix} \end{alignat*}​ux​vx​wx​​uy​vy​wy​​uz​vz​wz​​​​px​py​pz​​​​

yields the vector

p′⃗=(uxpx+uypy+uzpzvxpx+vypy+vzpzwxpx+wypy+wzpz)=(u⃗⋅p⃗v⃗⋅p⃗w⃗⋅p⃗)\vec{p'} = \begin{pmatrix} u_x p_x + u_y p_y + u_z p_z \\ v_x p_x + v_y p_y + v_z p_z \\ w_x p_x + w_y p_y + w_z p_z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \vec{u} \cdot \vec{p} \\ \vec{v} \cdot \vec{p} \\ \vec{w} \cdot \vec{p}\end{pmatrix}p′​=​ux​px​+uy​py​+uz​pz​vx​px​+vy​py​+vz​pz​wx​px​+wy​py​+wz​pz​​​=​u⋅p​v⋅p​w⋅p​​​

Each component is the scalar projection of p⃗\vec{p}p​ onto the basis vector u⃗,v⃗,w⃗\vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w} u,v,w.

Intuitively, the components in the resulting vector p′⃗\vec{p'}p′​ show the scalar amount showing into the respective direction.

To confirm that these projections are aligned with the original basis vectors, we rewrite:

p⃗=(u⃗⋅p⃗)u⃗+(v⃗⋅p⃗)v⃗+(w⃗⋅p⃗)w⃗\vec{p} = (\vec{u} \cdot \vec{p}) \vec{u} + (\vec{v} \cdot \vec{p}) \vec{v} + (\vec{w} \cdot \vec{p}) \vec{w}p​=(u⋅p​)u+(v⋅p​)v+(w⋅p​)w

Computing the dot product with a specific basis vector isolates its corresponding contribution:

p⃗⋅u⃗=(u⃗⋅p⃗)(u⃗⋅u⃗)+(v⃗⋅p⃗)(v⃗⋅u⃗)+(w⃗⋅p⃗)(w⃗⋅u⃗)=(u⃗⋅p⃗)(1)+(v⃗⋅p⃗)(0)+(w⃗⋅p⃗)(0)=u⃗⋅p⃗\begin{alignat*}{3} \vec{p} \cdot \vec{u} &= (\vec{u} \cdot \vec{p})(\vec{u} \cdot \vec{u}) + (\vec{v} \cdot \vec{p})(\vec{v} \cdot \vec{u}) + (\vec{w} \cdot \vec{p})(\vec{w} \cdot \vec{u})\\ &= (\vec{u} \cdot \vec{p})(1) + (\vec{v} \cdot \vec{p})(0) + (\vec{w} \cdot \vec{p})(0) \\ & = \vec{u} \cdot \vec{p} \end{alignat*}p​⋅u​=(u⋅p​)(u⋅u)+(v⋅p​)(v⋅u)+(w⋅p​)(w⋅u)=(u⋅p​)(1)+(v⋅p​)(0)+(w⋅p​)(0)=u⋅p​​

The same holds for v⃗\vec{v}v and w⃗\vec{w}w.

Thus, the vector p⃗′=Ap⃗\vec{p}' = \boldsymbol{A} \vec{p}p​′=Ap​ contains exactly the scalar projections of p⃗\vec{p}p​ onto the axes of the orthonormal basis, and the original vector can be reconstructed as a linear combination of the basis vectors scaled by those projections. □\Box□

Proof via Change-of-Coordinates​

We begin by introducing the Change-of-Coordinates Matrix Theorem3.

Change-of-Coordinates Matrix Theorem

Let B={b⃗1,b⃗2,…,b⃗n}B = \{\vec{b}_1, \vec{b}_2, \ldots, \vec{b}_n\}B={b1​,b2​,…,bn​} and C={c⃗1,c⃗2,…,c⃗n}C = \{\vec{c}_1, \vec{c}_2, \ldots, \vec{c}_n\}C={c1​,c2​,…,cn​} be bases of a vector space VVV. Then there is a unique n×nn \times nn×n matrix PC←B\underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}}C←BP​ such that

PC←B[x⃗]B=[x⃗]C\underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}} [\vec{x}]_B = [\vec{x}]_CC←BP​[x]B​=[x]C​

The columns of PC←B\underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}}C←BP​ are the CCC-coordinate vectors of the vectors in the basis BBB 4.
That is,

PC←B=([b1⃗]C[b2⃗]C…[bn⃗]C)\underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}} = \begin{pmatrix}[\vec{b_1}]_C &[\vec{b_2}]_C & \ldots & [\vec{b_n}]_C \end{pmatrix}C←BP​=([b1​​]C​​[b2​​]C​​…​[bn​​]C​​)

Proof (Existence): Given v⃗∈V\vec{v} \in Vv∈V, there exist scalars x1,x2,…,xnx_1, x_2, \ldots, x_nx1​,x2​,…,xn​ such that

v⃗=x1b1⃗+x2b2⃗+…+xnbn⃗\vec{v} = x_1\vec{b_1} + x_2\vec{b_2} + \ldots + x_n\vec{b_n}v=x1​b1​​+x2​b2​​+…+xn​bn​​

By the rules of matrix-vector multiplication, we can rewrite this equation to

v⃗=(b1␀␀⃗b2⃗…bn⃗)(x1x2⋮xn)\vec{v} = \begin{pmatrix} \vec{b_1} & \vec{b_2} & \ldots & \vec{b_n} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}x_1 \\ x_2 \\ \vdots \\ x_n \end{pmatrix}v=(b1​​​b2​​​…​bn​​​)​x1​x2​⋮xn​​​

Clearly, (x1,x2,…,xn)T(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n)^T(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)T represents [v⃗]B[\vec{v}]_B[v]B​, as it is the coordinate vector of v⃗\vec{v}v relative to the basis BBB.

Since BBB and CCC are bases for the same vector space, each bi⃗\vec{b_i}bi​​ can be expressed as a linear combination of vectors in CCC, that is, via [bi⃗]C[\vec{b_i}]_C[bi​​]C​.


Hence, we substitute bi⃗\vec{b_i}bi​​ with [bi⃗]C,1≤i≤n[\vec{b_i}]_C, 1 \leq i \leq n[bi​​]C​,1≤i≤n.

[v⃗]C=([b1⃗]C[b2⃗]C…[bn⃗]C)(x1x2⋮xn)[\vec{v}]_C = \begin{pmatrix} [\vec{b_1}]_C & [\vec{b_2}]_C & \ldots & [\vec{b_n}]_C \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}x_1 \\ x_2 \\ \vdots \\ x_n \end{pmatrix}[v]C​=([b1​​]C​​[b2​​]C​​…​[bn​​]C​​)​x1​x2​⋮xn​​​

We denote the left-hand matrix as

PC←B\underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}}C←BP​

Multiplying the contained coordinate vectors with the coordinates of v⃗\vec{v}v relative to BBB then yields the coordinates of v⃗\vec{v}v relative to CCC, as per rules of linear transformation.

[v⃗]C=PC←B[v⃗]B [\vec{v}]_C = \underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}} [\vec{v}]_B[v]C​=C←BP​[v]B​

□\Box□

Proof (Uniqueness):

Let [v⃗]C=M[v⃗]B ∀ v⃗∈V[\vec{v}]_C = \boldsymbol{M} [\vec{v}]_B\ \forall\ \vec{v} \in V[v]C​=M[v]B​ ∀ v∈V.

Replace v⃗\vec{v}v with b1⃗\vec{b_1}b1​​. Then [b1⃗]B=ε1⃗[\vec{b_1}]_B = \vec{\varepsilon_1}[b1​​]B​=ε1​​, i.e. (1,0,␀…,0)T(1, 0, \ldots, 0)^T(1,0,…,0)T of the standard basis. Hence, the first column of M\boldsymbol{M}M must be [b1⃗]C[\vec{b_1}]_C[b1​​]C​ to satisfy

[b1⃗]C=Mε1⃗[\vec{b_1}]_C = \boldsymbol{M} \vec{\varepsilon_1}[b1​​]C​=Mε1​​

Equally, for any i>1i > 1i>1, the iiith column of M\boldsymbol{M}M must be [bi⃗]C[\vec{b_i}]_C[bi​​]C​, since [bi⃗]B=εi⃗[\vec{b_i}]_B = \vec{\varepsilon_i}[bi​​]B​=εi​​:

[bi⃗]C=Mεi⃗[\vec{b_i}]_C = \boldsymbol{M} \vec{\varepsilon_i}[bi​​]C​=Mεi​​

Since any vector v⃗∈V\vec{v} \in Vv∈V is a linear combination of (linearly independent) basis vectors, the resulting coordinate vector in CCC can be written as a sum of the columns of M\boldsymbol{M}M weighted by the coordinates of [v⃗]B[\vec{v}]_B[v]B​.
Because the columns of M\boldsymbol{M}M are uniquely determined by the basis vectors, the resulting change-of-coordinates matrix M\boldsymbol{M}M is unique.

□\Box□

We now show that multiplying a vector p⃗\vec{p}p​ - that is, its coordinate representation [p⃗]ε[\vec{p}]_\varepsilon[p​]ε​ in the standard basis - with

A=(−u⃗−−v⃗−−w⃗−)\boldsymbol{A} = \begin{pmatrix} - \vec{u} - \\ - \vec{v} - \\ - \vec{w} - \end{pmatrix}A=​−u−−v−−w−​​

yields a vector whose components are the scalar projections of p⃗\vec{p}p​ relative to an orthonormal basis CCC, via a change-of-coordinates matrix.
This approach emphasizes the geometric interpretation of the transformation as a coordinate conversion from the standard basis to an arbitrary orthonormal basis and provides the theoretical foundation for the lookAt matrix introduced later.

We begin by computing the change-of-coordinates matrix Mε←C\underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{M}ε←CM​.

This matrix satisfies the following condition:

Mε←C[p⃗]C=[p⃗]ε\underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{\boldsymbol{M}} [\vec{p}]_C = [\vec{p}]_\varepsilonε←CM​[p​]C​=[p​]ε​

We can rewrite Mε←C\underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{M}ε←CM​ as

Mε←C=[[u⃗]ε [v⃗]ε [w⃗]ε]\underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{\boldsymbol{M}} = [ [\vec{u}]_\varepsilon\ [\vec{v}]_\varepsilon\ [\vec{w}]_\varepsilon ]ε←CM​=[[u]ε​ [v]ε​ [w]ε​]

since u⃗,v⃗,w⃗\vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w}u,v,w are the basis vectors of C. Obviously, since the target coordinate space is the standard basis

ε={[100],[010],[001]}\varepsilon = \begin{Bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \end{Bmatrix}ε=⎩⎨⎧​​100​​,​010​​,​001​​​⎭⎬⎫​

we are allowed to rewrite this as

Mε←C=[u⃗ v⃗ w⃗]\underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{\boldsymbol{M}} = [ \vec{u}\ \vec{v}\ \vec{w} ]ε←CM​=[u v w]

since the individual components of the basis vectors represented by the rows of A\boldsymbol{A}A already are the scalar projections onto the unit vectors of ε\varepsilonε.

Mε←C=AT\underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{\boldsymbol{M}} = \boldsymbol{A^T}ε←CM​=AT is now an orthogonal matrix

(uxvxwxuyvywyuzvzwz)\begin{pmatrix} u_x & v_x & w_x \\ u_y & v_y & w_y \\ u_z & v_z & w_z \end{pmatrix}​ux​uy​uz​​vx​vy​vz​​wx​wy​wz​​​

Since

(Mε←C)−1=MC←ε(\underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{\boldsymbol{M}})^{-1} = \underset{C \leftarrow \varepsilon}{\boldsymbol{M}}(ε←CM​)−1=C←εM​

and the inverse of an orthogonal matrix is simply its transpose [📖FH22, p. 118] it follows that

(Mε←C)−1=(AT)−1=(AT)T=A=MC←ε(\underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{\boldsymbol{M}})^{-1} = (A^T)^{-1} = (A^T)^{T} = A = \underset{C \leftarrow \varepsilon}{\boldsymbol{M}}(ε←CM​)−1=(AT)−1=(AT)T=A=C←εM​

This shows that AAA already provides a change-of-coordinates matrix from ε\varepsilonε to CCC. As such, any vector p⃗\vec{p}p​ multiplied with this matrix yields a coordinate vector whose components are the scalar projections of p⃗\vec{p}p​ relative to CCC:

Ap⃗=MC←ε[p⃗]ε=[p⃗]CA \vec{p} = \underset{C \leftarrow \varepsilon}{\boldsymbol{M}} [\vec{p}]_\varepsilon = [\vec{p}]_CAp​=C←εM​[p​]ε​=[p​]C​

We can therefore summarize:

   MC←ε [p⃗]ε=[p⃗]C⇔(MC←ε)−1 MC←ε [p⃗]ε=(MC←ε)−1 [p⃗]C⇔[p⃗]ε=Mε←C[p⃗]C\begin{alignat*}{3} & \qquad \quad \ \ \ \underset{C \leftarrow \varepsilon}{\boldsymbol{M}}\ &&[\vec{p}]_\varepsilon &&= [\vec{p}]_C\\ \Leftrightarrow &(\underset{C \leftarrow \varepsilon}{\boldsymbol{M}})^{-1}\ \underset{C \leftarrow \varepsilon}{\boldsymbol{M}}\ &&[\vec{p}]_\varepsilon &&= (\underset{C \leftarrow \varepsilon}{\boldsymbol{M}})^{-1} \ [\vec{p}]_C\\ \Leftrightarrow & \qquad \qquad &&[\vec{p}]_\varepsilon &&= \underset{\varepsilon \leftarrow C}{\boldsymbol{M}}[\vec{p}]_C \end{alignat*}⇔⇔​   C←εM​ (C←εM​)−1 C←εM​ ​​[p​]ε​[p​]ε​[p​]ε​​​=[p​]C​=(C←εM​)−1 [p​]C​=ε←CM​[p​]C​​

□\Box□

Change-of-Coordinates Example
Figure 1 The vector v expressed as coordinate vector relative to the bases B and C.
Plot-Code (Python)
import numpy as np
import math
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib.ticker import MultipleLocator


# Basis B
_, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6, 6))
ax.set_xlim(-3, 8)
ax.set_ylim(-3, 8)
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.set_xlabel( r'$x_B$')
ax.set_ylabel(r'$y_B$')
ax.grid(True)
ax.axhline(0, color='black', linewidth=1.5)
ax.axvline(0, color='black', linewidth=1.5)
ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(MultipleLocator(1))
ax.yaxis.set_major_locator(MultipleLocator(1))


#Basis C
e1 = np.array([0.5, -0.25])
e2 = np.array([0.25, 0.5])

ax.arrow(0, 0, *e1*24, color='blue', width=0.01, length_includes_head=True)
ax.arrow(0, 0, *e2*24, color='blue', width=0.01, length_includes_head=True)

ax.text(2.5, -2, r'$x_C$', color='blue', fontsize=12)
ax.text(1, 4, r'$y_C$', color='blue', fontsize=12)

grid_range = np.arange(-12, 20, 1)
for i in grid_range:
    p1 = i*e1 + grid_range[0]*e2
    p2 = i*e1 + grid_range[-1]*e2
    ax.plot([p1[0], p2[0]], [p1[1], p2[1]], color='blue', alpha=0.2)

for j in grid_range:
    p1 = grid_range[0]*e1 + j*e2
    p2 = grid_range[-1]*e1 + j*e2
    ax.plot([p1[0], p2[0]], [p1[1], p2[1]], color='blue', alpha=0.2)


# target vector 6, 2
ax.quiver(0, 0, 6, 2,  scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='red', width=0.005, linestyle='--')
ax.text(4,0.5, r'$\vec{v}$', color='red', fontsize=12)
circle_r = plt.Circle((6, 2), 0.08, color='red', fill=True)
ax.add_patch(circle_r)


ax.plot([0, 6], [2, 2], color='red', linewidth=1, linestyle='--')
ax.plot([6, 6], [0, 2], color='red', linewidth=1, linestyle='--')

ax.plot([4, 6], [-2,2], color='blue', linewidth=1, linestyle='--')

Figure 1 shows two different coordinate systems B,CB, CB,C that both span R2\mathbb{R}^2R2:

B={b1⃗, b2⃗}={(10),(01)},C={c1⃗, c2⃗}={(0.5−0.25),(0.250.5)}B = \begin{Bmatrix}\vec{b_1}, \ \vec{b_2} \end{Bmatrix} = \begin{Bmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}1 \\ 0\end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix}0 \\1\end{pmatrix}\end{Bmatrix}, C = \begin{Bmatrix}\vec{c_1}, \ \vec{c_2} \end{Bmatrix} =\begin{Bmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}0.5 \\ -0.25\end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix}0.25 \\0.5\end{pmatrix}\end{Bmatrix}B={b1​​, b2​​​}={(10​),(01​)​},C={c1​​, c2​​​}={(0.5−0.25​),(0.250.5​)​}

Obviously, since B=εB = \varepsilonB=ε, the vector v⃗=(6,2)T\vec{v} = (6, 2)^Tv=(6,2)T can be expressed as

[v⃗]B=[[b1⃗]B [b2⃗]B](62)=(1001)(62)=(62)[\vec{v}]_B = \begin{bmatrix} [\vec{b_1}]_B \ [\vec{b_2}]_B \end{bmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 6\\2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}[v]B​=[[b1​​]B​ [b2​​]B​​](62​)=(10​01​)(62​)=(62​)

We now derive the coordinates of v⃗\vec{v}v relative to the basis CCC. To construct [v⃗]C[\vec{v}]_C[v]C​, we need the columns [b1⃗]C[\vec{b_1}]_C[b1​​]C​ and [b2⃗]C[\vec{b_2}]_C[b2​​]C​ of the change-of-coordinates matrix PC←B\underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}}C←BP​.
These are obtained by expressing the basis vectors of BBB as linear combinations of the basis vectors of CCC:

x1c1⃗+x2c2⃗=(10)=b1⃗\begin{equation} x_1 \vec{c_1} + x_2 \vec{c_2} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \vec{b_1} \end{equation}x1​c1​​+x2​c2​​=(10​)=b1​​​​

and

x1c1⃗+x2c2⃗=(01)=b2⃗\begin{equation} x_1 \vec{c_1} + x_2 \vec{c_2} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \vec{b_2} \end{equation}x1​c1​​+x2​c2​​=(01​)=b2​​​​

Row-reducing the augmented matrix of equation (1)_ yields

(0.50.251−0.250.50)∼(101.6010.8)\begin{pmatrix} \begin{array}{cc|c} 0.5 & 0.25 & 1 \\ -0.25 & 0.5 & 0 \end{array} \end{pmatrix} \sim \begin{pmatrix}\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & 1.6 \\ 0 & 1 & 0.8 \end{array}\end{pmatrix}(0.5−0.25​0.250.5​10​​)∼(10​01​1.60.8​​)

Similarly, equation (2) gives

(0.50.250−0.250.51)∼(10−0.8011.6)\begin{pmatrix} \begin{array}{cc|c} 0.5 & 0.25 & 0 \\ -0.25 & 0.5 & 1 \end{array} \end{pmatrix} \sim \begin{pmatrix}\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & -0.8 \\ 0 & 1 & 1.6 \end{array}\end{pmatrix}(0.5−0.25​0.250.5​01​​)∼(10​01​−0.81.6​​)

Thus, the change-of-coordinates matrix PC←B\underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}}C←BP​ is

PC←B=(1.6−0.80.81.6)\underset{C \leftarrow B}{\boldsymbol{P}} = \begin{pmatrix} 1.6 & -0.8 \\ 0.8 & 1.6 \end{pmatrix}C←BP​=(1.60.8​−0.81.6​)

and we finally obtain

[v⃗]C=[[b1⃗]C [b2⃗]C][v⃗]B=(1.6−0.80.81.6)(62)=(88)[\vec{v}]_C = \begin{bmatrix} [\vec{b_1}]_C \ [\vec{b_2}]_C \end{bmatrix} [\vec{v}]_B = \begin{pmatrix} 1.6 & -0.8 \\ 0.8 & 1.6 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 8 \\ 8\end{pmatrix}[v]C​=[[b1​​]C​ [b2​​]C​​][v]B​=(1.60.8​−0.81.6​)(62​)=(88​)

□\Box□

Application: View Transformation and Camera Space in OpenGL​

Figure 2 shows a wireframe teapot mesh with a view camera targeted at it5. The interactive controls allow repositioning of the world and the view camera as well as the teapot, making it easy to visualize the different coordinate systems involved: The 3D world space versus the image produced by the camera6.

The abstracted camera also defines parameters for perspective projection, such as the field of view (fov) and the aspect ratio. However, for the purpose of constructing the view matrix, the most relevant parameters are the camera position, upxyz\text{up}_{xyz}upxyz​ and eyexyz\text{eye}_{xyz}eyexyz​, as they define the camera's position, its orientation and the view direction in world space. These parameters are used for constructing an orthonormal coordinate frame as we will show in the following sections.

In the graphics pipeline [📖VB15, p. 232], transforming world coordinates v⃗world∈Vworld\vec{v}_\text{world} \in V_\text{world}vworld​∈Vworld​ to camera coordinates v⃗cam∈Vcam\vec{v}_\text{cam} \in V_\text{cam}vcam​∈Vcam​ is typically the third step in the rasterization process, as illustrated in Figure 3.

Figure 3 An abstraction of the graphics pipeline. 'View' is responsible for mapping world-coordinate to view coordinates - that is, transforming points and vectors of the game world to an arbitrary camera, or point of view, most often determined through a player controlled camera. (Adapted from [Figure 7.1, 232, VB15]).

Defining Eye and Target Position​

The eye (or camera) position - labeled as Camera Position in Figure 2 - represents the location of the viewer in the world, also referred to as the vantage point.

As a position in VworldV_\text{world}Vworld​, it can either be represented as a point

eyexyz∈Rn\text{eye}_{xyz} \in \mathbb{R}^neyexyz​∈Rn

or equivalently as a vector from the origin

e⃗=eyexyz−(0,0,0)\vec{e} = \text{eye}_{xyz} - (0, 0, 0)e=eyexyz​−(0,0,0)

When moving freely in the world, the camera is directed at a point of interest (poi)

c∈Rnc \in \mathbb{R}^nc∈Rn

The pair (eyexyz,c)(\text{eye}_{xyz}, c)(eyexyz​,c) defines both the distance as well as the direction of the camera view. The forward vector f⃗\vec{f}f​, representing the viewing direction, is simply the difference between the point of interest and the camera position.

f⃗=c−eyexyz\vec{f} = c - \text{eye}_{xyz}f​=c−eyexyz​

Constructing the Camera Basis​

To construct a coordinate frame for the view space VcamV_\text{cam}Vcam​, a third component is required - the up⃗\vec{up}up​ - vector. This vector indicates the orientation of the camera's top - it can be thought of as the reference for the camera's vertical direction in view space. An intuitive analogy is a flight simulator: Rolling the airplane about its forward axis - the zzz-axis - effectively rotates the up⃗\vec{up}up​ vector and changes the percieved orientation of the game world.

In Figure 2, this up-direction is visualized by the small blue triangle on top of the view frustum.

Together with the forward vector f⃗\vec{f}f​, we can now construct an orthonormal camera frame for mapping points and vectors from VworldV_\text{world}Vworld​ to VcamV_\text{cam}Vcam​

Figure 4 Starting from the viewer’s position, the vector toward the point of interest, and a given up‑vector, the camera’s coordinate system is constructed by orthonormalization. Note, that this illustration does not consider OpenGL's negative z-axis convention.
Plot-Code (Python)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import math


fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10, 10))
ax = fig.add_subplot(projection='3d')

ax.set_xlim([0, 5])
ax.set_ylim([0, 5])
ax.set_zlim([0, 5])

ax.set_xlabel('x')
ax.set_ylabel('z')
ax.set_zlabel('y')

ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, color='grey', length=5, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)
ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 0, 1, 0, color='grey', length=5, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)
ax.quiver(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1, color='grey', length=5, arrow_length_ratio=0.04)

ax.view_init(elev=10, azim=-45)

camcol="black"
upcol="green"
poicol="purple"
camzcol="blue"
camxcol="red"
camycol="green"

eye = np.array([2, 2, 2])
poi = np.array([2, 5, 3])
up = np.array([1, 0, 1])
up_norm = up / np.linalg.norm(up)

camz = poi - eye
camz_norm = camz / np.linalg.norm(camz)

camx = np.linalg.cross(camz_norm, up_norm)
camx_norm = camx / np.linalg.norm(camx)

camy_norm = np.linalg.cross(camx_norm, camz_norm)
camy_norm = camy_norm / np.linalg.norm(camy_norm)

ax.text(*(poi - [0, -.3, -0.1]), r'$c$', color=poicol, fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')
ax.text(*(eye - [0, 0.6, 0.0]), r'$\text{eye}_{xyz}$', color=camcol, fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

ax.scatter(*eye, color=camcol, s=50)
ax.scatter(*poi, color=poicol, s=50)

ax.quiver(*eye, *(camz), color='#000000', alpha=0.3,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05, linestyle="--")

ax.quiver(*eye, *(up_norm), color=upcol, alpha=0.6,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
ax.text(*(eye + [0, 0.6, 0.6]), r'$\vec{up}$', color=upcol, alpha=0.6, fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

ax.quiver(*eye, *(camx_norm), color=camxcol,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
ax.text(*(eye + [0, 0.1, -0.6]), r'$\vec{\text{cam}}_\text{x}$', color=camxcol, fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

ax.quiver(*eye, *(camz_norm), color=camzcol,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
ax.text(*(eye + [0, 0.5, -0.1]), r'$\vec{\text{cam}}_\text{z}$', color=camzcol, fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

ax.text(*(eye + [0, 1.9, 0.4]), r'$\vec{f}$', fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

ax.quiver(*eye, *(camy_norm), color=camycol,  arrow_length_ratio=0.05)
ax.text(*(eye + [0, -0.3, 0.4]), r'$\vec{\text{cam}}_\text{y}$', color=camycol, fontsize=12, horizontalalignment='left')

plt.subplots_adjust(left=0, right=1, top=1, bottom=0)
plt.show()

Although the OpenGL specifications explicitly state that

"OpenGL does not force left- or right-handedness on any of its coordinate systems."7

we adopt the widely accepted conventions found in standard textbooks and the OpenGL reference documentation itself ([📖SWH15]): These conventions assume a right-handed coordinate system in which the viewer looks down the negative zzz-axis, the positive xxx-axis extends to the right, and the positive yyy-axis points upward8.

Figure 4 shows a given up vector up⃗\vec{up}up​, the vantage point eyexyz\text{eye}_{xyz}eyexyz​ as well as ccc as the observed point. eyexyz\text{eye}_{xyz}eyexyz​ and ccc let us derive the forward vector f⃗\vec{f}f​. This vector - as well as subsequent vectors used in the following computations - is normalized.

We obtain cam⃗z\vec{cam}_zcamz​, which will serve as the zzz-axis of the required orthonormal basis of the camera space:

eyexyz−c∣eyexyz−c∣=cam⃗z\frac{\text{eye}_{xyz}-c}{|\text{eye}_{xyz}-c|} = \vec{cam}_z∣eyexyz​−c∣eyexyz​−c​=camz​
OpenGL z-axis conventions

Note that we subtract the point of interest ccc from the camera position eyexyz\text{eye}_{xyz}eyexyz​ to obtain a vector pointing in the opposite direction of the view vector in world space (eyexyz−c=−f⃗\text{eye}_{xyz}-c = - \vec{f}eyexyz​−c=−f​). This inversion is necessary because the resulting camera space expects the view direction to be aligned with the negative zzz-axis9.

cam⃗z\vec{cam}_zcamz​ and up⃗\vec{up}up​ allow us to construct a perpendicular vector cam⃗x\vec{cam}_xcamx​, which becomes the xxx-axis of the camera frame:

up⃗×cam⃗z∣up⃗×cam⃗z∣=cam⃗x\frac{\vec{up} \times \vec{cam}_z}{|\vec{up} \times \vec{cam}_z|} = \vec{cam}_x∣up​×camz​∣up​×camz​​=camx​

To complete the basis, we compute cam⃗y\vec{cam}_ycamy​. While one might be tempted to use up⃗\vec{up}up​ directly, it is not guaranteed to be orthogonal to f⃗\vec{f}f​, since f⃗\vec{f}f​ is not a predefined axis but computed as the direction vector from eyexyz\text{eye}_{xyz}eyexyz​ to ccc. Consequently, up⃗\vec{up}up​ may be slightly tilted toward or away from f⃗\vec{f}f​, as illustrated in Figure 410.

cam⃗z×cam⃗x=cam⃗y\vec{cam}_z \times \vec{cam}_x = \vec{cam}_ycamz​×camx​=camy​

The derivation of the coordinate vector of point ccc from world space to camera space is illustrated in Figure 5. In the figure, the camera is positioned behind the point of interest. As a result, the point - while located on the positive x-axis in world coordinates - is mapped onto the negative x-axis in the camera image.

Figure 5 Illustration of the orthonormalization process and the resulting camera image in a right-handed coordinate system. The bold lines represent the basis vectors of the camera coordinate frame. The point c is located on the positive x-axis in world space, but is projected onto the negative x-axis in the camera image due to the coordinate transformation.

Transforming the World into Camera Space​

Finally, we can construct the change-of-coordinates matrix Pcam←world\underset{cam \leftarrow \text{world}}{\boldsymbol{P}}cam←worldP​.

Note that VworldV_\text{world}Vworld​ is represented by the standard basis ε\varepsilonε. Therefore, the matrix

(camx⃗1camy⃗1camz⃗1camx⃗2camy⃗2camz⃗2camx⃗3camy⃗3camz⃗3)=Pworld←cam\begin{pmatrix} \vec{cam_x}_1 & \vec{cam_y}_1 & \vec{cam_z}_1 \\ \vec{cam_x}_2 & \vec{cam_y}_2 & \vec{cam_z}_2 \\ \vec{cam_x}_3 & \vec{cam_y}_3 & \vec{cam_z}_3 \end{pmatrix} = \underset{world \leftarrow \text{cam}}{\boldsymbol{P}}​camx​​1​camx​​2​camx​​3​​camy​​1​camy​​2​camy​​3​​camz​​1​camz​​2​camz​​3​​​=world←camP​

contains the scalar components of the basis vectors of the camera frame expressed in world coordinate system. Its transpose yields the actual change-of-coordinates matrix from world to camera space:

(camx⃗1camx⃗2camx⃗3camy⃗1camy⃗2camy⃗3camz⃗1camz⃗2camz⃗3)=Pcam←world\begin{pmatrix} \vec{cam_x}_1 & \vec{cam_x}_2 & \vec{cam_x}_3 \\ \vec{cam_y}_1 & \vec{cam_y}_2 & \vec{cam_y}_3 \\ \vec{cam_z}_1 & \vec{cam_z}_2 & \vec{cam_z}_3 \end{pmatrix} = \underset{cam \leftarrow \text{world}}{\boldsymbol{P}}​camx​​1​camy​​1​camz​​1​​camx​​2​camy​​2​camz​​2​​camx​​3​camy​​3​camz​​3​​​=cam←worldP​

We now derive the translation vector T⃗3×1\vec{T}_{3 \times 1}T3×1​ used to complete the transformation.

By convention, the view camera is located at the origin (0,0,0)(0, 0, 0)(0,0,0) and oriented to look down the negative zzz-axis. Objects that result in positive zzz-coordinates relative to the camera are typically clipped respectively culled from the final image.

To align the world such that the camera resides at the origin, we perform a translation by the negative eye position. This yields the following homogeneous translation matrix:

(100−eyex010−eyey001−eyez0001)\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & -\text{eye}_x \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -\text{eye}_y \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & -\text{eye}_z \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}​1000​0100​0010​−eyex​−eyey​−eyez​1​​

With translation applied first, followed by rotation, we finally derive the complete lookAt-matrix

MlookAt=(Pcam←worldT⃗3×101)\boldsymbol{M}_{\text{lookAt}} = \begin{pmatrix} \underset{\text{cam} \leftarrow \text{world}}{\boldsymbol{P}} & \vec{T}_{3 \times 1} \\ 0 & 1\end{pmatrix}MlookAt​=(cam←worldP​0​T3×1​1​)

as the product of rotation matrix and translation matrix11

MlookAt=(camx⃗1camx⃗2camx⃗30camy⃗1camy⃗2camy⃗30camz⃗1camz⃗2camz⃗300001)(100−eyex010−eyey001−eyez0001) =(camx⃗1camx⃗2camx⃗3−(camx⃗⋅eye⃗)camy⃗1camy⃗2camy⃗3−(camy⃗⋅eye⃗)camz⃗1camz⃗2camz⃗3−(camz⃗⋅eye⃗)0001)\begin{alignat*}{3} \boldsymbol{M}_{\text{lookAt}} &= \begin{pmatrix} \vec{cam_x}_1 & \vec{cam_x}_2 & \vec{cam_x}_3 & 0\\ \vec{cam_y}_1 & \vec{cam_y}_2 & \vec{cam_y}_3 & 0 \\ \vec{cam_z}_1 & \vec{cam_z}_2 & \vec{cam_z}_3 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & -\text{eye}_x \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -\text{eye}_y \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & -\text{eye}_z \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \ \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \vec{cam_x}_1 & \vec{cam_x}_2 & \vec{cam_x}_3 & -(\vec{cam_x} \cdot \vec{eye})\\ \vec{cam_y}_1 & \vec{cam_y}_2 & \vec{cam_y}_3 & -(\vec{cam_y} \cdot \vec{eye}) \\ \vec{cam_z}_1 & \vec{cam_z}_2 & \vec{cam_z}_3 & -(\vec{cam_z} \cdot \vec{eye}) \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \end{pmatrix} \end{alignat*}MlookAt​ ​=​camx​​1​camy​​1​camz​​1​0​camx​​2​camy​​2​camz​​2​0​camx​​3​camy​​3​camz​​3​0​0001​​​1000​0100​0010​−eyex​−eyey​−eyez​1​​=​camx​​1​camy​​1​camz​​1​0​camx​​2​camy​​2​camz​​2​0​camx​​3​camy​​3​camz​​3​0​−(camx​​⋅eye​)−(camy​​⋅eye​)−(camz​​⋅eye​)1​​​
Derivation of the lookAt Matrix via Stepwise Inversion

(In the following, we implicitly assume that, whenever a 3×13\times 13×1 vector n⃗\vec{n}n is multiplied by a 4×44\times 44×4 matrix, n⃗\vec{n}n is interpreted as a homogeneous vector by appending a 111 as its fourth component.)

Let ci⃗\vec{c_i}ci​​ be the basis vectors of the camera space, expressed as coordinate vectors relative to the standard basis (that is, the basis of the world space).

The change-of-coordinates matrix (Pcam←world)−1=Pworld←cam(\underset{\text{cam} \leftarrow \text{world}}{\boldsymbol{P}})^{-1} = \underset{\text{world} \leftarrow \text{cam}}{\boldsymbol{P}}(cam←worldP​)−1=world←camP​ is given by

(c1xc2xc3xc1yc2yc3yc1zc2zc3z)\begin{pmatrix} c_{1_x} & c_{2_x} & c_{3_x} \\ c_{1_y} & c_{2_y} & c_{3_y} \\ c_{1_z} & c_{2_z} & c_{3_z} \end{pmatrix}​c1x​​c1y​​c1z​​​c2x​​c2y​​c2z​​​c3x​​c3y​​c3z​​​​

Mapping a vector v⃗cam\vec{v}_\text{cam}vcam​ from camera to world space gives

v⃗world=(c1xc2xc3xc1yc2yc3yc1zc2zc3z)v⃗cam\vec{v}_\text{world} = \begin{pmatrix} c_{1_x} & c_{2_x} & c_{3_x} \\ c_{1_y} & c_{2_y} & c_{3_y} \\ c_{1_z} & c_{2_z} & c_{3_z} \end{pmatrix} \vec{v}_\text{cam}vworld​=​c1x​​c1y​​c1z​​​c2x​​c2y​​c2z​​␀​c3x​​c3y​​c3z​​​​vcam​

However, to account for the position of the camera eyexyz\text{eye}_{xyz}eyexyz​ - that is, the origin of the camera coordinate frame in world coordinates - we add e⃗\vec{e}e (=eyexyz−(0,0,0)=\text{eye}_{xyz} - (0,0,0)=eyexyz​−(0,0,0)) to the rotated camera-space vector R(v⃗cam)\boldsymbol{R}(\vec{v}_\text{cam})R(vcam​).

Hence, we obtain a transformation matrix

v⃗world=(c1xc2xc3xexc1yc2yc3yeyc1zc2zc3zez0001)v⃗cam\vec{v}_\text{world} = \begin{pmatrix} c_{1_x} & c_{2_x} & c_{3_x} & e_x \\ c_{1_y} & c_{2_y} & c_{3_y} & e_y \\ c_{1_z} & c_{2_z} & c_{3_z} & e_z \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \vec{v}_\text{cam}vworld​=​c1x​​c1y​​c1z​​0​c2x​​c2y​​c2z​​0​c3x​​c3y​​c3z​​0​ex​ey​ez​1​​vcam​

How can we justify an inverse of this matrix through reasoning alone?

Since the original transformation from camera to world space consists of a rotation, followed by a translation, the inverse must reverse these steps - undo translation, then undo rotation:

v⃗cam=(Pworld←cam)−1 T(−e⃗) v⃗world\vec{v}_\text{cam} = (\underset{\text{world} \leftarrow \text{cam}}{\boldsymbol{P}})^{-1}\ \boldsymbol{T}(-\vec{e}) \ \vec{v}_\text{world}vcam​=(world←camP​)−1 T(−e) vworld​

where (Pworld←cam)−1(\underset{\text{world} \leftarrow \text{cam}}{\boldsymbol{P}})^{-1}(world←camP​)−1 is the inverse of Pcam←world\underset{\text{cam} \leftarrow \text{world}}{\boldsymbol{P}}cam←worldP​, and T(−e⃗)\boldsymbol{T}(-\vec{e})T(−e) is a transformation matrix that adds −e⃗-\vec{e}−e component wise from the vector multiplied with it.

Obviously, due to associativity of matrix multiplications, we can compute the rotation-translation matrix first, which gives us

(Pworld←cam)−1 T(−e⃗)=(Pcam←world−(c1⃗⋅e⃗)−(c2⃗⋅e⃗)−(c3⃗⋅e⃗)01)(\underset{\text{world} \leftarrow \text{cam}}{\boldsymbol{P}})^{-1}\ \boldsymbol{T}(-\vec{e}) = \begin{pmatrix} \underset{\text{cam} \leftarrow \text{world}}{\boldsymbol{P}} & \begin{matrix} -(\vec{c_1} \cdot \vec{e}) \\ -(\vec{c_2} \cdot \vec{e}) \\ -(\vec{c_3} \cdot \vec{e}) \end{matrix} \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}(world←camP​)−1 T(−e)=​cam←worldP​0​−(c1​​⋅e)−(c2​​⋅e)−(c3​​⋅e)​1​​

Multiplying the vector v⃗world\vec{v}_\text{world}vworld​ with this matrix will yield

(Pworld←cam)−1 T(−e⃗) v⃗world=(c1xc1yc1z−(c1⃗⋅e⃗)c2xc2yc2z−(c2⃗⋅e⃗)c3xc3yc3z−(c3⃗⋅e⃗)0001)(vworldxvworldyvworldz1)=(c1xc1yc1z−(c1⃗⋅e⃗)c2xc2yc2z−(c2⃗⋅e⃗)c3xc3yc3z−(c3⃗⋅e⃗)0001)(vworldxvworldyvworldz1)=(vworldxc1x+vworldyc1y+vworldzc1z−(c1⃗⋅e⃗)vworldxc2x+vworldyc2y+vworldzc2z−(c2⃗⋅e⃗)vworldxc3x+vworldyc3y+vworldzc3z−(c3⃗⋅e⃗)1)=((vworldx−ex)c1x+(vworldy−ey)c1y+(vworldz−ez)c1z(vworldx−ex)c2x+(vworldy−ey)c2y+(vworldz−ez)c2z(vworldx−ex)c3x+(vworldy−ey)c3y+(vworldz−ez)c3z1)=((v⃗world−e⃗)⋅c1⃗(v⃗world−e⃗)⋅c2⃗(v⃗world−e⃗)⋅c3⃗1)=v⃗cam\begin{alignat*}{3} (\underset{\text{world} \leftarrow \text{cam}}{\boldsymbol{P}})^{-1}\ \boldsymbol{T}(-\vec{e}) \ \vec{v}_\text{world} &= \begin{pmatrix} c_{1_x} & c_{1_y} & c_{1_z} & -(\vec{c_1} \cdot \vec{e}) \\ c_{2_x} & c_{2_y} & c_{2_z} & -(\vec{c_2} \cdot \vec{e}) \\ c_{3_x} & c_{3_y} & c_{3_z} & -(\vec{c_3} \cdot \vec{e})\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} {v_\text{world}}_x \\ {v_\text{world}}_y \\ {v_\text{world}}_z \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} c_{1_x} & c_{1_y} & c_{1_z} & -(\vec{c_1} \cdot \vec{e}) \\ c_{2_x} & c_{2_y} & c_{2_z} & -(\vec{c_2} \cdot \vec{e}) \\ c_{3_x} & c_{3_y} & c_{3_z} & -(\vec{c_3} \cdot \vec{e})\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} {v_\text{world}}_x \\ {v_\text{world}}_y \\ {v_\text{world}}_z \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} {v_\text{world}}_xc_{1_x} + {v_\text{world}}_yc_{1_y} + {v_\text{world}}_zc_{1_z} -(\vec{c_1} \cdot \vec{e}) \\ {v_\text{world}}_xc_{2_x} + {v_\text{world}}_yc_{2_y} + {v_\text{world}}_zc_{2_z} -(\vec{c_2} \cdot \vec{e}) \\ {v_\text{world}}_xc_{3_x} + {v_\text{world}}_yc_{3_y} + {v_\text{world}}_zc_{3_z} -(\vec{c_3} \cdot \vec{e})\\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} ({v_\text{world}}_x - e_x)c_{1_x} + ({v_\text{world}}_y - e_y)c_{1_y} + ({v_\text{world}}_z- e_z)c_{1_z} \\ ({v_\text{world}}_x - e_x)c_{2_x} + ({v_\text{world}}_y - e_y)c_{2_y} + ({v_\text{world}}_z- e_z)c_{2_z} \\ ({v_\text{world}}_x - e_x)c_{3_x}+ ({v_\text{world}}_y - e_y)c_{3_y} + ({v_\text{world}}_z- e_z)c_{3_z}\\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} (\vec{v}_\text{world} - \vec{e})\cdot \vec{c_1} \\ (\vec{v}_\text{world} - \vec{e})\cdot \vec{c_2} \\ (\vec{v}_\text{world} - \vec{e})\cdot \vec{c_3}\\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ &= \vec{v}_\text{cam} \end{alignat*}(world←camP​)−1 T(−e) vworld​​=​c1x​​c2x​​c3x​​0​c1y​​c2y​​c3y​​0​c1z​​c2z​​c3z​​0​−(c1​​⋅e)−(c2​​⋅e)−(c3​​⋅e)1​​​vworld​x​vworld​y​vworld​z​1​​=​c1x​​c2x​​c3x​​0​c1y​​c2y​​c3y​​0​c1z​​c2z​​c3z​​0​−(c1​​⋅e)−(c2​​⋅e)−(c3​​⋅e)1​​​vworld​x​vworld​y​vworld​z​1​​=​vworld​x​c1x​​+vworld​y​c1y␀​​+vworld​z​c1z​​−(c1​​⋅e)vworld​x​c2x​​+vworld​y​c2y​​+vworld​z​c2z​​−(c2​​⋅e)vworld​x​c3x​​+vworld​y​c3y​​+vworld​z​c3z​​−(c3​​⋅e)1​​=​(vworld​x​−ex​)c1x​​+(vworld​y​−ey​)c1y​​+(vworld​z​−ez​)c1z​​(vworld​x​−ex​)c2x​​+(vworld​y​−ey​)c2y​​+(vworld​z​−ez​)c2z​​(vworld​x​−ex​)c3x​​+(vworld​y​−ey​)c3y​​+(vworld​z​−ez​)c3z​​1​​=​(vworld​−e)⋅c1​​(vworld​−e)⋅c2​​(vworld​−e)⋅c3​​1​​=vcam​​

Here, v⃗world−e⃗\vec{v}_\text{world} - \vec{e}vworld​−e yields a vector relative to the origin of the camera coordinate frame - the first step in the reverse operation (undo translation).

This vector is then projected onto the respective standard basis vectors, expressed in the camera basis ([ε⃗i]c[\vec{\varepsilon}_i]_c[εi​]c​), which form the rows of (Pworld←cam)−1(\underset{\text{world} \leftarrow \text{cam}}{\boldsymbol{P}})^{-1}(world←camP␀␀​)−1 (undo rotation).

The result is the same as if translation was applied first to v⃗world\vec{v}_\text{world}vworld​ and then rotated:

((v⃗world−e⃗)⋅c1⃗(v⃗world−e⃗)⋅c2⃗(v⃗world−e⃗)⋅c3⃗1)=(c1xc1yc1z0c2xc2yc2z0c3xc3yc3z00001)(100−ex010−ey001−ez0001)(vworldxvworldyvworldz1)=(c1xc1yc1z0c2xc2yc2z0c3xc3yc3z00001)(vworldx−exvworldy−eyvworldz−ez1)\begin{alignat*}{3} \begin{pmatrix} (\vec{v}_\text{world} - \vec{e}) \cdot \vec{c_1} \\ (\vec{v}_\text{world} - \vec{e}) \cdot \vec{c_2} \\ (\vec{v}_\text{world} - \vec{e}) \cdot \vec{c_3}\\ 1 \end{pmatrix} &= \begin{pmatrix} c_{1_x} & c_{1_y} & c_{1_z} & 0 \\ c_{2_x} & c_{2_y} & c_{2_z} & 0 \\ c_{3_x} & c_{3_y} & c_{3_z} & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 & -e_x \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -e_y \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & -e_z \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} {v_\text{world}}_x \\ {v_\text{world}}_y \\ {v_\text{world}}_z \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} c_{1_x} & c_{1_y} & c_{1_z} & 0 \\ c_{2_x} & c_{2_y} & c_{2_z} & 0 \\ c_{3_x} & c_{3_y} & c_{3_z} & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} {v_\text{world}}_x -e_x \\ {v_\text{world}}_y -e_y \\ {v_\text{world}}_z -e_z \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\\ \\ \end{alignat*}​(vworld​−e)⋅c1​​(vworld​−e)⋅c2​​(vworld​−e)⋅c3​​1​​​=​c1x​​c2x​​c3x​​0​c1y​​c2y​​c3y​​0​c1z​​c2z​​c3z​​0​0001​​​1000​0100​0010​−ex​−ey​−ez​1​​​vworld​x​vworld​y​vworld​z​1​​=​c1x​​c2x​​c3x​​0​c1y​​c2y​​c3y​​0​c1z​​c2z​​c3z​​0​0001​​​vworld​x​−ex​vworld​y​−ey​vworld​z​−ez​1​​​
